author: Colleen McCain Nelson   and   William Mauldin
title: U.S., China to announce new steps to fight climate change - MarketWatch
text:
The U.S. and China Friday will announce significant new steps in their efforts to combat climate change, including a pledge by China to launch a program by 2017 to cap some emissions and put a price on carbon, senior Obama administration officials said Thursday.
The announcements will detail the two countries’ strategies for reaching emissions targets and aim to bolster efforts to complete an international accord to reduce global carbon-dioxide emissions, which is meant to be wrapped up in December. The Obama administration officials, touting a new era of U.S.-China climate diplomacy, said the statement would demonstrate to the world the countries’ commitment to reaching agreed-upon targets.
Chinese President Xi Jinping’s decision to put a price on CO2 emissions with a cap-and-trade system marks the first time China has launched such an initiative.
Senior administration officials said the emissions trading system would encompass a wide range of sectors that produce a substantial percentage of climate pollution, including the paper, steel and cement industries. It would mark an evolution from a series of regional test programs already under way in China, U.S. officials said.
While China has operated cap-and-trade systems on a pilot basis, officials said the planned launch of the emissions-trading system is a significant policy undertaking by the Chinese.
Friday’s announcements are the culmination of several months of discussions among U.S. and Chinese officials as the Obama administration tries to build momentum ahead of United Nations climate-change negotiations in Paris later this year.
